content.text: JavaScript Switch Statement
The switch statement is used to perform different actions based on different conditions.
content.html: The switch statement is used to perform different actions based on different conditions.

content.text: The JavaScript Switch Statement
Use the switch statement to select one of many code blocks to be executed.
content.html: Use the switch statement to select one of many code blocks to be executed.

content.text: Syntax

content.code_html:
switch(expression) {
  case x:
    // code block
     break;
  case y:
    // code block
     break;
  default:
    // code block
 }

content.text: This is how it works:
content.html: This is how it works:

content.code_html:
switch (new Date().getDay()) {
  case 0:
    day = "Sunday";
    break;
  case 1:
    day = "Monday";
    break;
  case 2:
     day = "Tuesday";
    break;
  case 3:
    day = "Wednesday";
    break;
  case 4:
    day = "Thursday";
    break;
  case 5:
    day = "Friday";
    break;
  case 6:
    day = "Saturday";
}

content.text: The break Keyword
When JavaScript reaches a break keyword, it breaks out of the switch block.
content.html: When JavaScript reaches a break keyword, it breaks out of the switch block.

content.text: This will stop the execution inside the switch block.
content.html: This will stop the execution inside the switch block.

content.text: It is not necessary to break the last case in a switch block. The block breaks (ends) there anyway.
content.html: It is not necessary to break the last case in a switch block. The block breaks (ends) there anyway.

content.text: Note: If you omit the break statement, the next case will be executed even if the evaluation does not match the case.
content.html: Note: If you omit the break statement, the next case will be executed even if the evaluation does not match the case.

content.text: The default Keyword
The default keyword specifies the code to run if there is no case match:
content.html: The default keyword specifies the code to run if there is no case match:

content.code_html:
switch (new Date().getDay()) {
  case 6:
    text = "Today is Saturday";
    break;
  case 0:
    text = "Today is Sunday";
    break;
  default:
    text = "Looking forward to the Weekend";
}

content.text: The default case does not have to be the last case in a switch block:
content.html: The default case does not have to be the last case in a switch block:

content.code_html:
switch (new Date().getDay()) {
  default:
    text = "Looking forward to the Weekend";
    break;
  case 6:
    text = "Today is Saturday";
    break;
  case 0:
    text = "Today is Sunday";
}

content.text: If default is not the last case in the switch block, remember to end the default case with a break.
content.html: If default is not the last case in the switch block, remember to end the default case with a break.

content.text: Common Code Blocks
Sometimes you will want different switch cases to use the same code.
content.html: Sometimes you will want different switch cases to use the same code.

content.text: In this example case 4 and 5 share the same code block, and 0 and 6 share another code block:
content.html: In this example case 4 and 5 share the same code block, and 0 and 6 share another code block:

content.code_html:
switch (new Date().getDay()) {
  case 4:
  case 5:
    text = "Soon it is Weekend";
    break;
  case 0:
  case 6:
    text = "It is Weekend";
    break;
  default:
    text = "Looking forward to the Weekend";
}

content.text: Switching Details
If multiple cases matches a case value, the first case is selected.
content.html: If multiple cases matches a case value, the first case is selected.

content.text: If no matching cases are found, the program continues to the default label.
content.html: If no matching cases are found, the program continues to the default label.

content.text: If no default label is found, the program continues to the statement(s) after the switch .
content.html: If no default label is found, the program continues to the statement(s) after the switch.

content.text: Strict Comparison
Switch cases use strict comparison (===).
content.html: Switch cases use strict comparison (===).

content.text: The values must be of the same type to match.
content.html: The values must be of the same type to match.

content.text: A strict comparison can only be true if the operands are of the same type.
content.html: A strict comparison can only be true if the operands are of the same type.

content.text: In this example there will be no match for x:
content.html: In this example there will be no match for x:

content.code_html:
let x = "0";
switch (x) {
  case 0:
    text = "Off";
    break;
  case 1:
    text = "On";
    break;
  default:
    text = "No value found";
}

content.text: Exercise ? What is this? Test your skills by answering a few questions about the topics of this page
Which one is NOT a keyword in the switch statement?
content.html: Which one is NOT a keyword in the switch statement?
